product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Alex
content: The Amazon Echo has not improved at all in voice recognition since the first generation. It's this bipolar extreme between good voice recognition and absolute horrific make you want to smash your head into a brick wall frustration. The Echo Show for what it is supposed to be able to do is incredibly inadequate and this is something that I feel should be obvious. This is 2019. Not 1995. We live in a world where even crappy cell phones can go back to apps that were opened ANYTHING that you're doing, is completely interrupted when you ask it something else, and then afterwards, there's absolutely NO WAY to get back to what you were doing without it starting over as if it totally quit the program AFTER you asked it to switch back to it. For instance, there's a built in web browser (Just so you don't think this is skill-related and maybe Amazon pass the buck). Let's say I'm browsing a page.. Could be anything like. Any page. I then say "What's the weather like?" It takes me away from the page to show me the weather and say it also of course. At the end if I say "resume firefox" or whatever it literally will go to the OPENING of the browser as if I had NOTHING open. Same with the Twitch skill. So I will say "open <streamer>" and it will open the stream. Cool. then I wanted to know the weather. Cool got the weather. But now Twitch isn't being shown, so I say "resume Twitch" ... it goes to the purple Twitch home screen "X channels you follow are online. Would you like to see them?" no. when I say resume Twitch I want you to !@&*(^&*^ resume what was playing before I asked what the weather was. This is so basic functionality it's not even funny. To continue the story, I then proceed to say "Ask twitch for <streamer>" TWENTY TIMES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! To which EVERY TIME Alexa says "I dont' recognize that streamer name" then other times it opens up Wikipedia to something completely unrelated that I DID NOT SAY. So I end up resorting to asking it to open Twitch and then tapping the options on screen as if I'm using a Tablet, completely defeating the purpose of a FREAKING VOICE ASSISTANT. Now a more simpler thing. With Google Home you can say "Turn on the energize" and it knows it's in whatever room it's in so it will turn on the lights with that scene in that room. Or you can say "Turn on the energize  everywhere" and it will turn that scene on in every room in the house. OR you can say "Turn on the energize in the dining room" while in the bedroom. Alexa? Not a chance. I mean yes. You set up rooms. Yes. You put Alexa in a certain room. No. She doesn't seem to know what room she's in nor can she turn on ANYTHING in that room without you being AS FULLY EXPLICIT.. "Turn on the energize in the bedroom" .. even though you're in the bedroom, because saying "Turn on the energize" is met with "There are multiple devices with that name, can you tell me which one you want?" then it's like defusing a bomb, because saying the natural response to that question "<name of device>" is met with "I'm sorry. I didn't understand that." Basically you have to GIVE IT THE FULL COMMAND as if it has absolutely ZERO understanding of language or anything else. In other words it's primitive as a straw hut in the middle of the jungle. Amazing idea, implemented boneheadedly awful. And sad to say this is why other devices are running circles around it. For all the features that Echo Show is supposed to have, it is ruined by it's complete incompetence at voice control. And once you realize that you cannot even REMOTELY talk to it like you'd talk to something that even TRIES to mimick human conversation, it still won't understand you half the time, as evidence by me telling it to go to the streamer that I just said once and it understood and then it fails to understand twelve times and I have to actually just press buttons to get there because the voice command is garbage. I pre-ordered the first Amazon Echo and still have it. The voice command has not improved AT ALL since then. Having a continue mode where it listens again for a follow up command is NOT better speech recognition. It's just code. You need better AI, by like a billion lightyears of a long shot. If it didn't perform the basic functions of controlling the lights etc. with learnable , though less convenient commands, I would return it. I don't even want to install additional skills on it because my experience using it to watch Twitch has probably taken ten years off my life. I'll just use the computer the old fashioned way because IT WORKS.
title: Completely Incompetent for Anything But The Most Basic Inquiries

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Shopaholic
content: Bought this on Amazon Prime day on July 15, 2019. I have all the other Alexa's in my home and set up is usually very easy. This was very difficult, it took us hours to get the sound working and that was turning it on and off and resetting the device numerous times. It worked for one day and then stopped. Called customer service the next day and they stated that many of the devices that were sent out for Prime day are not working properly and there is no volume. The resolution I got was, hold on to it for four or five days and hopefully they will do an update to fix it. No suggestion to send it back or send a new one. Basically keep your fingers crossed and hopefully Amazon will fix the problem on the hundreds of units that have already complained about this issue. When you're playing a video and tell Alexa to stop, it does not stop. You literally have to scream at it to go back to home. The suggestions and captions all day long scrolling are really really annoying, you should be able to change this! Putting your photos on in the slideshow doesn't work properly either. You constantly get Amazon backgrounds coming up. What a disaster this was in ordering! You would think a brand new item they would at least let you send back. Like I want to wait 5 days and hope that the problem gets fixed with an update? How can hundreds of units go out like this? This was a very unprofessional and horrible mistake on Amazon's part.
title: Issue with many new units sent out July 2019

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Commander Schlock
content: I have five Echo's and smart home stuff all over the house. I use my Echos daily for alarms, changing the heat/AC, lights, timers, weather, news and podcasts and as an intercom. I was expecting to be pretty happy with the Show, but out of the box it has potential that has yet to be realized, at least from what I can tell. First, I thought video news would be great. Reuters was what I tried. It plays, but then I ask Alexa to exit. Instead of stopping, it simply shuts off the video, but the audio continues to play. Seriously, this is annoying. I tried a few recipe skills and they were quite clumsy, difficult to exit and one even wanted me to sign up online. Hello, I want to do everything on the Show, not go to some website. Why is this so complicated? The constant stream of various headlines and "trending topics" is annoying. Can I shut them off? I have yet to figure that out. So, with all the hype on developing a "delightful user experience" why do we have to start from zero with a new medium/platform? Why can't Amazon or Skill developers apply good UI design and make this not just easy to use, but fun? I'll add more later, but first impressions do matter. My new iPad, Kindle and other devices were a lot of fun right away. This should be too. Sadly the experience is more like buying a fussy new printer than an innovative new device. I am returning this. It is nothing but a machine to play dumb games on.
title: Out of the box I am not impressed. Usability is subpar, many skills are gimmicks

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Jim Lewis
content: I previously gave the 2nd. Gen. Show 3-stars for having no manual.  However, on actually firing it up, WOW!  I got it for two basic reasons: 1) to be able to display multiple named timers and not having to keep asking Alexa, "How much time is left on my pizza timer?," and, 2) to be able to quickly ask, "Show me the Front Door" without having to fiddle with my smartphone or computer to see what's going on with my Ring Video Doorbell.  It works great for both purposes and is pretty handy for other things.  I like seeing any math calculation results displayed on the screen, too, as opposed to just trusting that I heard all numbers dictated to my DOT the right way. The display and sound quality are just fine as far as I'm concerned.  The device is on an open kitchen table several feet from any walls but the aluminum blinds on a kitchen picture window form a nice reflective backdrop to send sound forward. I bought the official Amazon plastic stand.  It holds the Show firmly enough but is kinda stiff to adjust.  A metal stand with more tilt and rotation may be in my future. One of the most annoying things, though, is the Discovery and Rotate Continuously modes.  I turned both off and it worked initially but when I had some quirks getting notified by my Ring Doorbell, I tried turning those display modes back on and now I haven't been able to turn Discovery and Rotate Continuously off since!  Hope to avoid the Factory Reset nuclear option.  What does work to give me a non-distracting blank screen is just to say, "Echo, turn off screen." The Ring Doorbell was a bit tricky to get working right.  Have a nice Linksys Router that does both 5 GHz and 2.4 GHz bands with the doorbell about the only thing on the 5 GHz channel and given highest possible router priority.  Figured since Show is not battery-powered and is close by router, I'd put it on the 5 GHz channel, too, the better to get notifications from the Ring Doorbell.  Bad idea!  Only when I put the Show on the 2.4 GHz router channel did doorbell rings trigger Show notifications (I could view front door video from either channel, though).  Figured when I pressed the doorbell, it began to hog 5 G channel to transmit video and the 2.4 GHz channel would be freer to communicate with router for video feed.  The notification and switch to video upon request are now pretty fast and reliable. In spite of no manual in the box, there is plenty of on-screen Show help available.  What does seem a little schizophrenic is the Settings interface on the Show, in the Alexa Android app, and on the alexa.amazon.com interface are all a bit different.  Would be nice to have more commonality of interface and more advice that one needs to go to the alexa.amazon.com site or whatever for some operations.  I liked the Show and the Black Friday Sales price so much that I bought Show 5's for our daughters but I forgot to uncheck the "Automatically Link Device to my Amazon Account" ordering option that is automatically checked as the default even when ordering as a gift!  I had to go to the alexa.amazon.com site to be able to "factory reset" the device ordered for the daughter to remove it from my Amazon account!  Crazy!  (told her if I saw anyone ordering baby clothes on my account, I'd know who it was!) Amazon has clearly put a lot of cleverness and intelligence into these devices, e.g., when I say, "Cancel all timers," Alexa complies and cancels all timers set on the device, then reminds me that there is also one still running set on a Dot and would I like to cancel that one, too.  Or, not having adjusted to calling the Show "Echo" to distinguish it from the "Alexa" Dot, if I tell Alexa on the Dot to cancel a timer actually set on the Show, the Dot is smart enough to know about the Show timer and do what I asked, advising what it has done.  Would be nice, though, if it would stay on the timer screen upon request.  The count time is displayed in pretty large font - the name of the timer is ridiculously small, though.  The user ought to have a way to configure timer display and relative timer order and command running timer display by voice, etc. ("Make my Pizza timer full-screen and show me the last countdown minute.") So all in all, it seems like a great device for a bargain $150 Black Friday Sale price.  Still lots of bugs to be worked out.  Trying to find the interface and behavior that makes everyone happy must be a Sisyphean chore.  But the Show has no trouble understanding my voice at a distance over the roar of the kitchen exhaust fan.  It's performance has been great, so far. I do ask Alexa/Echo weather questions, directions and store hours, general knowledge questions, etc.  I did gripe to Amazon that when one asks the Show for directions and traffic, the Show only gives you verbally expected travel time with a traffic report and a hint of routing but you have to go to the Alexa app to see a map of a proposed route - ridiculous for a little computational device with a great screen connected to powerful servers.  I also asked Alexa several times in different ways for travel times and hours to a specific local Post Office and Alexa insisted on giving me directions to another Post Office about as nearby in the opposite direction that I wanted to travel!  I expect better on such things.  Will have to see how calendaring and tasking work and interface with Toodledo and Microsoft calendaring tools that I use. The other weird Amazonian thing was that I sprung for the $5 Amazon Smart Plug bundled as part of my shopping spree.  When I saw the order invoice, the price on the Show had been reduced to something like $132 and the price on the plug jacked up to $22-since the total price was the same and I did order a bundle with the Amazon stand, I had nothing much to complain about.  And the Show is a truly fine device at its Black Friday price!
title: In Spite of No Manual, One Helluva Cool and Useful Device

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Brian M.
content: I‚Äôve really liked the 1st generation Echo Show and so when I say the features of the 2nd generation I quickly preordered it. I replaced all 4 of my 1st generation Echo Shows with 2nd generation Echo Shows and repurposed the older ones. The screen is a big improvement on the 2nd Gen, you can really notice the size difference and the new screen looks a lot clearer. We use this for streaming cameras too and as a baby monitor and night and you can see all the detail you need to see. The sound is improved as well. I listen to Pandora pretty much all day long on the Show in my office and for the size and footprint of it the sound quality is great. I will say the one thing I noticed, as far as audio goes, when you ask Alexa to turn up/down the volume vs. using the button the voice command jumps what seems to be a couple steps and I find myself having to go over and turn it down manually if it has gotten too loud. I get around this gernally by saying a specific level i.e. ‚ÄúAlexa, set the volume to 4‚Äù. Overall I‚Äôm very happy I upgraded to the 2nd generation Echo Shows!
title: A Great Upgrade From the 1st Gen Echo Show

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: B. Lynn Stubblefield
content: After trying this device for a few months I've decided that it is the most useless device offered by amazon.  The alexa/echo commands rarely work, tHe screen resolution is 1970's in appearance....I could go on but now I see that amazon has lowered the price substanially and I know why....
title: Useless device....

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Drew Anderson
content: Updates:  I have updated this and I gave it another star. There is an Amazon-produced youtube video that is worth watching.  However it isn't in the Amazon help, and it isn't referenced by any of the Amazon help. It gives some of the basics of the device.  I found it on google. You can find it by searching for "Echo Show Basics" and it is about 3.5 minutes long. If you watch the video, the device will be less infuriating and can easily be made less presumptive. In the book "1984" there was a telescreen.  It was always listening.  Always watching. I always wondered how these devices might come into existence and into peoples homes. I think that I just bought one.  Maybe I'm just afraid that I just bought one. BTW, I do have an Echo, and I like it. The Show, however, is another story. The default mode is for it to be constantly doing something on the screen, switching between "cards" which present separate types of information. I spent most of today searching for or figuring out how to turn things off. The home card/screen starts out with lots of stuff turned on. (That is the presumptive part.) Trending topics, sports scores, upcoming events, Discovery with Alexa are all on, but you can turn them off. The one thing you cannot turn off is the Try "Alexa, ..." hint at the bottom of the screen I searched for hours on how to turn this off.  It even displays when you are listening to music. (This is what "infuriating" is referring to in the title!) The default mode when playing songs is to show the lyrics.  There doesn't seem to be a setting in the any of the various settings options to change this.  However, if you tap the progress bar for a song while it is playing, it will bring up controls.  There is a "Lyrics" button.  I'm sure I just dense, but it took me a while to find this. I also feel much more paranoid about the camera than I thought I would, even with it disabled. I am not very happy with the device and wish that I never bought it.  Hopefully, it will improve over time. I understand that some competitive devices have a shutter. Some things I do like: The multiple timer screen is pretty nice.  But, if you set a timer on one device, the other device doesn't know about it. Sound is pretty good.  Another reviewer mentioned that the movie volume is noticeably less than the music or Alexa volume.  I also found this to be true. The display is good. Some things it doesn't suggest, but should: "Alexa, go home" "Alexa, go to settings" "Alexa, turn off screen" "Alexa, stop streaming"  This will cause it to release the stream so that another device can stream something.
title: Presumptive and somewhat Infuriating device

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Naomi
content: For those who are debating an Alexa device with screen capabilities, this will depend on what you want to use it for. In taking the smart home plunge, I ended up purchasing 4 Echo Shows (2nd generation) and 2 Facebook Portal+‚Äôs for my home because I wanted both, PA & Drop in function, but also a primo video chat. Here‚Äôs why I have both: The Echo Show (2nd generation) exceeds the Portal + in overall functionality. It provides all of the features of the previous model and more. I wanted some (or all) of my primary devices to sometimes act as a PA & also be able to use the ‚ÄòDrop in‚Äô feature when I am not home. I live in a condo and have an 8wk old puppy coming. Though I work from home, at some point if I need to go on a run or leave for an hour or two, I am still able to access the camera and speak to her if she‚Äôs barking at the front door. For now, Facebook Portal does not have this feature. With the Echo Show there is also no need for an external hub for most of my smart devices because it‚Äôs built right in. I‚Äôm unsure if Portal has this. With the Show, there is also direct access to the internet. Just ask Alexa to play movie trailers, Prime videos, etc. The display is nice, but I would chalk up the video calling and ‚ÄòDrop in‚Äô quality to better than that of my security cameras (also high quality). The Facebook Portal+ display and AI camera technology far exceeds that of any other device I‚Äôve used. I purchased this for the calling feature - which is its‚Äô primary function. During a call, you no longer need to employ being your own camera man during the call - it‚Äôs completely hands-free and smoothly follows you around the room like a movie director. I was impressed by the range at which it accurately followed me and will even follow in the direction of your voice if you happen to step out of the frame. Very limited on other functions though and I expect more are soon to follow within the year once the ‚Äòdata breach‚Äô blah blah stuff calms down a bit. Though the Portal does not support the PA & ‚ÄòDrop in‚Äô functions that the Echo Show has, I can still control all of my smart home devices & groups with ease and employ all of my routines with no problem. If you‚Äôre looking for all-around functionality and more features the Echo Show (2nd) is the way to go. If quality video calling is the priority, then you can‚Äôt beat the Portal+ for now - it far exceeds everything else in that arena.
title: Echo Show (2nd) or Facebook Portal+? - Great functionality with the Echo Show (2nd)

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: TXEggplant
content: *UPDATE* When I got this device, I brought my old Show over to my parents, who are in their 80s. They had a Dot before, so they weren't totally new to the devices. I had showed them how to call me on the Dot, and they used it to call other family members too. Once we got the Shows in both homes, it wasn't long before they were dropping in on me on a regular basis. I thought, at first, that it might be intrusive but there is a CLEAR tone that someone is dropping in and you have about 15-30 seconds before the view comes in to focus. I love it. They just dropped in to find out when we would be traveling to see them. My mom told me about the cookies she made and I could see my dad eating them LOL. I like to be able to drop in on them to see how they are. When I'm away from home, I like to drop in on my own house to see what's going on and make sure it's all OKAY there. It might take a bit to get your elderly parents set up on the Show but it's totally worth it. You can restrict access to certain times or completely. It's done by contact, not device. You can also set it up to go to your cell phone, I believe, with the Alexa app. So, my update is not just about the device itself (but the newest Show is AWESOME ... I didn't know if it was worth upgrading but it IS) but also about it's functionality with faraway loved ones :) The sound is AMAZING! A huge step up from the previous Show. I love the bigger screen!
title: *UPDATED* Great sound and great for those with elderly parents or distant relatives

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Twit
content: Would have been a nice device to have but did you really have to put your "Try This..." into it. Send it back after using it for only a few hours and spending a lot of time talking with Amazon techs to resolve the problem.  After a number of calls to Amazon I was finally told you cannot get rid of Try This... Stupid move on your part Amazon.  Like a lot of other people commented:  You can have a nice photo montage running and those idiotic Try This...  keeps showing at the bottom of the screen. Had high expectations for this device and you shot it out of the sky.... Nice move dummies
title: Stupid Reminders on how to use Alexa

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Sheila S
content: Purchased the Echo Show (2nd Gen) It has changed my life, or actually changed my 91 year old aunt's life. Thank you! Thank you! Thank You! This device should be marketed more to assist caregivers it is truly a life saver. The screen comes up with her prompts to take her medication everyday at 8pm and she seeks us out to get her medication. I am not sure anyone who has not done caregiving for a memory challenged individual understand what this means but it is life changing. Echo tells her to turn her favorite TV shows on, it gives both a visual and verbal cue so she is reading! My Aunt is reading her messages and she processes them and acts upon them. And we can drop in, ok that is a little more challenging but she is learning, still looks around for who is talking to her :). I leave activities for her to do and with nanny camera she is actually doing them. Turns out she is very busy during the day and not just sitting in her favorite chair sleeping. She is given down time during day to take naps and does take a few naps. She prefers not to go to senior center saying she prefer young people. She also does puzzles, sweeps floors, folds the laundry I leave for her, cannot put it away but she is folding it. She usually more active in the warmer months so as winter approaches I need to find more activities that Echo can provide. I am also learning how to program echo, I would like to be able to maybe put her favorite show on the Echo and at least let her watch Golden Girls once or twice a week. Amazon if you have not done this I implore you to continue to develop devices for memory challenged adults, technology is the future that will extend individuals ability to remain in their homes and or their family/caregivers homes. Once again Thank you, and I highly recommend people experiment with Echo Show, or Google Nest, or any device that provides home assistance.
title: Incredible Device for the Elderly with Memory Challenges

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: mswlogo
content: We bought this for Grand Pa that can barely use a flip phone. We had to create an Amazon Account for Grand Pa in order to Import Contacts for Grand Pa because there is no other way to get contacts into the unit. We do NOT want Grand Pa's Echo Show using our Primary Amazon Account nor have access to our Sensitive Contacts that other people visiting Grand Pa could access. So we used a wiped un-activated spare phone and added Grand Pa's contacts there. Went to import Contacts into Alexa App which was logged into Grand Pa's Amazon account and it said you need to validate your phone number. So we had to validate it with my wife's phone. Bzzt that phone is locked to another account (the account we use for our Echo Show to talk to Grand Pa with). We also wanted other relatives of Grand Pa to be "dropped in on" (which is the easiest way Grand Pa could contact someone) by Grand Pa. That requires every one have an Echo Show. This is NOT for Grand Pa.
title: Smart Phone REQUIRED for Grand Pa

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: EMarieB
content: I wanted one of these devices for the longest time...I don't know why!!!! To say I'm disappointed with this purchase is an understatement!  I really want to return this device and the tower echo and buy the Google Portal.  This thing is so limited its unreal.  I didn't know I couldn't access the internet to watch videos...this was not published well. I can't make video calls very easy either, it's always voice calls - even to those with the echo show.  I tried to get Alexa to tell me how to re-heat corn on the cob and she kept giving me recipes for corn on the cob.  Even when I speak slowly and articulate carefully, I still have issues.  I need to check the return policy...as I sit here writing, I'm more upset. UGH. Save your money and time - don't buy this device or the other echo.
title: Rethink this purchase...

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Jesse K.
content: I was super excited about receiving the 2nd Gen Echo Show today. But, after spending a few hours with it, I‚Äôm not that impressed. I‚Äôll start off by saying the sound quality and output is amazing, other than that, I‚Äôm struggling to find a good use for it. I‚Äôll give a full rundown below: Backstory: This is my first ‚Äúscreened‚Äù echo product. Originally, I was thinking this would have similar features to an android tablet. I wanted to use it in the kitchen and run some of my cooking/recipe ‚Äúapps‚Äù on it. I somehow missed the memo that the Show is essentially an echo dot with a screen, and you can only choose from the limited ‚ÄúAmazon Skills‚Äù selection from the Alexa app using voice control. *In full disclosure and ‚ÄúTMI‚Äù, I‚Äôm on a strict low-carb/ sugar-free diet - the native recipe skill is almost useless for me...* I know, I know, you can watch prime and other videos on it, but I have no idea why you would want to watch something on a 10‚Äù tabletop screen when your TV is 10x bigger, or on a tablet that's 50x thinner... There is almost zero personalization available and everything seems to be locked down. Heck, I can‚Äôt even select items or information (like 5-day weather, news, calendar) to display on the home screen. Unless I‚Äôm missing something here, looks like the whole operating system literally just runs off the voice-controlled ‚Äúskills‚Äù. Out of curiosity, I went ahead and ordered the Fire HD 10‚Äù tablet with ‚ÄúShow Dock‚Äù, and I'm glad I did... With the Fire Tablet, I'm able to run the apps I like and it's completely mobile. I don't have the sound quality that the Show had, but this can easily be fixed with a nice Bluetooth speaker.
title: About as much functionality as an Echo Dot with a Screen...

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Kenny
content: Update (12/19/18): Today I tried watching some Youtube videos. I noticed within 5 minutes, the Echo would close the browser entirely and go back to the home screen. ARE YOU KIDDING ME!!! I never owned an electronic device that pissed me off so much. I'm ready to make my own Youtube video (that you would have to watch on any other device except the Echo Show) of me shooting this piece of garbage and FINALLY getting some enjoyment out of it. Update (12/17/18): So I've had my Show for 2 months and I have to say that nothing really changed. It still remains an expensive disappointment. There has been an issue since the beginning where after watching so many videos on Prime Video, the show will no longer play videos until the device is restarted. My volume down and mute buttons are going to wear out from having restarted it so much. I have to do this about every 2 days. I know it needs to be restarted because when trying to play a video of any kind from any source, the Show will perform really slow and seem to load for a minute or two when selecting a video, then just back out and not play anything. This is kind of ridiculous. At the time of writing this, there is still no Netflix either. I see the Shows are sold out until after Christmas. I hope people aren't buying these as gifts or they're going to have some pretty disappointed spouse's/relatives. I previously wrote a review with more stars, but the more I use the Echo Show, The more i'm starting to dislike it. Watching the movies that you own on Prime Video is a nightmare. Once you get a movie or show playing, it works fine. But the voice commands to get certain movies to play is a nightmare. Name a certain movie and she will say it back wrong, or say she couldn't find it. Try saying play whatever from my library, and she thinks it's a skill. It's super frustrating. Have Alexa turn lights off during a movie and the movie pauses for about a minute so it can show you a toggle button for you lights. Pause a movie? it'll stay paused for about a minute, then go to the home screen, to which there is no "resume" or "continue movie" command. You have to tell her to play whatever show or movie again. I bought this to replace an old Samsung tablet that I had on my desk to watch Youtube or Netflix while doing other things. I miss those days to be completely honest. I should have stuck with the regular screenless Echo that I had.
title: Sound is impressive, that's about it

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: C. Hampson
content: Thought this would be a great idea for my 100 year old grandmother. Turns out she has to also have a cellphone number. Ok... that isn't happening, thanks for highlighting that as a requirement for this unit to function =\
title: Don't buy this for an elderly person unless they have a cellphone

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Janet Littlejohn
content: We are a family of 7, and currently have 5 other Alexa devices in various rooms around the house. Our household uses the devices on a daily basis. I was pretty excited about the possibility of the Echo show. We could use it in the kitchen for the family calendar! Or for recipes! Or maybe to watch a show! Oh the possibilities! We bought their 2 for $120 off deal black Friday 2018. I was intending on giving one of the units to the in-laws for Christmas and putting the other in our kitchen. The in-laws were wanting something that showed a nice big clock with the date and day of the week (among other things). I figured that the show would definitely be able to do that! Turns out I was sorely mistaken. The clock is a small little thing in the top corner that is not customizable at all. No date, no day of the week. But hey, at least it has a calendar right?.. that is essentially useless. It only shows one or two days, or not even a day if you have multiple things on the calendar. It doesn't even highlight what the current day it is! There is no monthly or weekly view, just a extremely zoomed in view of 1 or two appointments. There is no option to customize anything. You get what you get. Why would you have a calendar without a week/month view? We also were thinking it would be great for recipes. Turns out that because I'm in Canada, close to none of the 'standard' skills even work. Amazon has geolocked the recipes skill!?!? Ok, so no problem we can't use the recipes skill that is advertised clearly on the side of the box. I'll get over that and use the browser to show a recipe. So, I opened up the browser to a recipe site and started cooking dinner. After a couple minutes, the device times out and returns to the home screen! "Alexa, reopen my browser" should get me back to the page I was on right? No! It takes me back to the home page and I have to navigate to the recipe again. Rinse and repeat every two minutes until I give up and open up a physical cookbook. EVERYTHING that I wanted to do with this device doesn't work. No clock, no calendar, no recipies, no netflix, no <insert whatever you think it will do here>. I'm sure that all these things will all get addressed in time,but right now it really falls short. I gave this 3 stars because the actual physical product is excellent. Quality is great, speakers sound really good, screen is bright. I have no complaints about anything physical on the device. It really is a very nice physical product, but the firmware is close to completely useless for anything that I want to do with it. I will most likely return the units I bought. Maybe I'll buy them again once they have addressed some of the things that would actually make this useful.
title: So much potential... but completely uncustomizable.

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Kimberly
content: Very disappointed at this product. I was very excited to utilize this at home, but I come to find out after trying to use it for something else other than music that Alexa doesn't seem to find anything online, its unable to show videos or music videos and its a hassle to link with other devices, when asked to do a task it takes three or for times for her to actually understand what you're saying or it gives you random information for an answer
title: Save your money

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Christina Wagner
content: This is really a glorified intercom. Bought a mix of echo dots and shows for the house this year for Christmas. Upon getting to know the system, i realized that you can only stream music on two devices at once. So I looked into it and you can create a household that lets 2 adults, 2 teens and 2 kids to stream music but this again will cost you 150 dollars a year to make that work. Also, i decided to move all of my photos and music to amazon so that it was all in one place. After a 40 minute phone call with customer service, i learned that you are now unable to upload any music bought on any other platform to amazon music. So I have amazon music unlimited but they are still asking me to pay for music that i have previously purchased. This is very upsetting. Also, supposedly you get unlimited photos being a prime member but as i was uploading my photos......all of a sudden i was told that i was out of space and had to pay more to store and backup my photos. My advice buy a google home or an apple product depending on where you store your music and videos.
title: Dont bother buying

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: William Stevens
content: 20181108: I bought two new Echo Shows several days ago, one at home, one for the office. The good stuff: 1. Easy to set up. I had the Show up and functional in under 15 minutes. It was already registered to me, all I had to do was rename it (based on the room I placed it in). Downloading the Alexa iPhone app made setup even easier. Within about 30 minutes I had most of the home smart devices connected, included Nest devices and the SmartThings hub. 2. Good sound. I don't think it will compete with a Sonos or the new Apple Homepod, but the sound is good, and for most applications, more than good enough. 3. Very nice to have the calendar and other life-organizing items pulled in from Google and other sources to show on the screen. 4. Does a nice job showing recipes. 5. It will read your kindle books to you. The bad stuff: 1. Alexa doesn't handle names very well. And, if you have names in SmartThings that weren't fully thought out, you may run into a few problems. To clean up the labels for a voice-activated environment, I had to carefully rename a number of items and groups, ensuring that no words overlapped. That can be a challenge with multiple Hue lamps and other smart devices in the same room. Naming the lamps kitchen 1, kitchen 2, and kitchen 3 works great, until you also want a group called Kitchen Lights.... Same for the porch lights, and so on. In the end, I've renamed almost every device with some name that is not directly overlapping with the group I want it in (usually a group will be a room). 2. The device sits with the screen, and the camera, at an angle. This is OK if you are reading a list, but not so great if you want to use DropIn either as an intercom, or to check on your home while you are away. As I mentioned in my Echo Spot review, mostly you get a great view of the ceiling. For the hefty price take (about $220) the device should allow adjustment of the camera angle. 3. The unit is made to sit on a surface, a shelf or a counter. It would be great to be able to wall mount it, but that won't happen without some special hardware. One other item to discuss: all Alexa devices require a login. You can login with the same account on all of them, which solves some problems, but causes others. I have a wife and two kids. Alexa assumes everyone is me, because I logged in with my Amazon account on all the devices. So? It means the reminders are mine, the alarms are mine, the calendars are mine... all my stuff on every device. Amazon, if you really want to make Alexa useful, you need to make Alexa family-aware. If my son updates the calendar on the Spot in his room, it should stay with him, and he doesn't need to know about my appointments. The Echo Show in the kitchen is a community device for the entire house, but the Spot or Dot on the nightstand should be much more personal, especially for alarms and calendars. And Drop In should work for all the devices, no matter who the device is personalized for.
title: I nice-to-have item, but it needs more work

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Room + Goods
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. Amazon 2018 Echo Show has added 3 key features that improves the overall experience of the Echo Show - Larger display w/ better design, improved sound quality, and upgraded entertainment options. Took away one star - wish I didn't always have to repeat some commands. Needs to improve understanding commands. For those people who mentioned the clock/weather is TOO SMALL, please look at the last photo. You can magnify the clock/information  by going to Settings > Accessibility
title: Amazon added 3 huge Features

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: M Stack
content: Replacement update: still 1 star Made sure to keep volume at a max of 50 and turned bass below 50. How other people aren't getting a VERY noticeable rattle on  mid bass is beoyomd me. 30 minute update: 2 stars to 1. A speaker just blew while playing at 50% volume. Absolutely  ridiculous. Just received the new show, and not impressed. We have all of the other Echo products and this one is probably the biggest let down. The screen gets it the two stars, but the sound/speakers are a HIGE miss. Without front speakers it is just odd and very obvious the sound is being blocked by the screen. Sorry, but the old show had it right with the front facing speakers. I'll give it a couple of days, but this one is probably going back with the price it commands.
title: Rear speakers are a miss

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Gary Anderson
content: This product could be great. But it is not. The screen options are the main problem. Every 6 seconds a message pops up that says "Try Alexa ......" . This is not an option. You are just stuck with it. Every 6 seconds. It gets really annoying really quick. Amazon starting doing this with the Fire Stick 4k also. It stinks. Also, The screen times out and shuts off after a few minutes. Again this is not an option. You are stuck with it. If I want my screen to stay on that's too bad for me. I can't. Why would you even have a screen device and then just shut it off without the option to keep it on. I have to keep tapping the screen to wake it up. It stinks.
title: Screen Options Stink!

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: JATOAV8OR
content: I purchased this Show 2nd gen and two Show 5s. The (big) show was installed in my 87 yr old mothers home. She has advanced arthritis in her hand, is totally deaf in one ear & can‚Äôt hear out of the other. She also suffers from cataracts so her vision is less than ideal. To try and communicate via telephone is extremely difficult. Her landline is almost useless. She cant see god enough to use a smartphone so we‚Äôre left with a poor quality flip phone with a really weak speaker. Since installing the Show gen 2 in her home it‚Äôs changed her life for the better, it really truly has. The sound is so bold & clear that she has no problems at all hearing calls. The touch screen is very sensitive, just a light touch make the selection. My mom is very picky and normally resistant to change and was suspicious of this new technology. She really likes her new (video phone) it‚Äôs won her over. It‚Äôs big & loud & intuitive. I  now have no problem communicating  with her several times a day using the two Show 5s I purchased. This is one of the best purchases I‚Äôve made in quite a while. I highly recommend both the echo show second generation and echo show five.
title: Excellent For Elderly Mother

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: My Public Name
content: It set itself up. Honestly, it knew which WiFi network to use and the password (assume Amazon has it stashed in the cloud somewhere under my name). So that was nice. Watching Prime video works fairly well, but it can be hard to get exactly what  you want without interacting with the touch screen (or possibly the remote, haven't tried that for anything but volume). On some shows and movies, it insists on bringing up a list of episodes, which can be scrolled through by intoning "next" and "previous" over and over. Other content plays immediately, picking up wherever I left off. Hooked up Hulu as well, and telling the thing to "watch Seinfeld" worked automatically, bypassing Amazon Video where I don't have the rights. It picked up where I last left off and was able to advance episodes with "next episode", but "previous episode" unceremoniously dumped me on a Hulu list. Saying "next episode" on last episode put on to another series that is apparently part of "My Stuff" on Hulu. Added the Echo Recast for off-the-air, which also works fairly well, but oddly enough it tries to launch Hulu to watch CBS. That doesn't work as I don't have Hulu Live. Oddly, NBC loads right up and ABC presents a poser: use Recast or Hulu. Telling it "1" for Recast works, but it would be nice if it would remember such decisions (with an interface to reset defaults). Using the "channel guide" command shows all of the expected channels (including CBS), so it's a bit of a mystery as to why it thinks CBS is only available on Hulu. As for YouTube, the first command I tried was "watch cat videos" to see how bad the YT experience would be (thanks to a feud between Google and Amazon). Should have realized that the command didn't invoke YT at all. Later on asking for YT content, I was asked to choose between Silk or Firefox browsers. Choosing the former allowed for using YT through the touch screen. Suspect content integration is non-existent, though it should be able to at least search. Haven't bothered as YT is mostly a waste of time anyway. Interfaces with the usual Alexa suspects of shopping (of course), checking the calendar, managing lists, setting alarms and timers, listening to music (now with lyrics), reading Kindle books, etc. are enhanced considerably by the screen. Phone calls worked as expected with an added visual interface; same for home automation. However, it seems that most 3rd party skills do not take advantage of the screen. Speaking of home automation, I don't see a visual interface for setting scenes, but suspect they will work through voice. No sign of notifications. Every other Alexa device I have lights up and beeps to indicate a new message. Would seem like a no-brainer to put these on the screen. Or perhaps the rotating display on the home screen covers these sorts of missives (mostly shopping related). Sound is great, video looks great as well (though 720p I think). Certainly this is the best alarm clock ever.
title: Nice smart display with some bugs to shake out

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Ron Killian
content: We had 2 show 5's and really like them, so this bigger unit was a great addition to the growing system. Love the big bright and quality screen. While the sound is not quite has good as our HK's, it's still very nice and this thing gets pretty loud. Also love the drop in feature to have video from/to other show units, can see using this more in the future. Plus once we get camera's, it will just be better. Set up was simple, just follow the steps on the screen. It does take some time to update and "optimize", but once it's done, it's done. I agree the constant tips, while nice sometimes, do get old after as while. The only issue I have is the stupid lack of interaction for youtube and netflix. Funny this comes bundled with Hulu, but NOT netflix or youtube.  Gee, wonder why. These days it should! The Hulu integration works so well, it should be the same for netflix. I read a questions one one asked about netflix and I can't believe all the negative, snarky and crappy comments. Seriously? This is a big screen, many people will put it in the kitchen (as we did) and many people spend some time in their kitchen (as we do), so some will want to watch Netflix or youtube. I am just so tired of all these tiff's between these big companies. Get over yourself, the ONLY ones that are losing out or being inconvenienced is the CONSUMER. Shame on you. Maybe some day, Google, Walmart, Netflix or Amazon will be the bigger person and think about what matters most, the consumer. Okay rant over. Over all, very happy with the unit.
title: Love it for the most part, one rant

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: R Young
content: I already had an Echo Dot in my kitchen, but I thought the Echo Show would be nice to have in there so I could see timers, watch some videos, see recipes and I liked that it could act as a digital photo frame as well. The original show was pretty dated looking so I skipped it, but the (2nd gen) Echo Show looks so much better. Software: This is the biggest problem with the Echo Show so I'm leading with it. The software is really designed poorly. If it has a huge 10" touch screen, why not design the software to let you use touch AND voice. Want to go to a website? You can't just click on a browser, you have to ask it to "Open Firefox" or "Open Silk". Want to quickly pull up a list of your timers currently running? You can't, you have to ask it. Want to search from a Prime Movie to watch while cooking? You have to do it with your voice and it's very cumbersome. If you're watching a video and want to set a timer, it closes out the video. When a timer is running, it's not always displayed, so you are left wondering how much time is left and have to ask her. When you use it as a photo frame (using the Prime Photos app on your phone or computer)  the photo you use is muted (no where near as nice looking as it is on the Google Home Hub) and it's constantly you to "Try asking Alexa to....". The whole thing is really poorly designed from a visual perspective. Thankfully that can be solved with software updates if Amazon tries. Display: The screen is beautiful and viewable from anywhere in the room. I find it to be a good size, in fact, it was one of the reasons I didn't go with the Google Home Hub. With a 7" screen, that was just too small to be useful. Sound: It's a huge upgrade from my Echo Dot. It has a nice full sound and I rarely have the volume over 40%. Voice Control: It does a great job at hearing the call phrase "Alexa" from anywhere in the room and even in adjacent rooms Overall, it's a good device with a lot of potential. Hardware-wise, it's top notch. Beautiful display, great sound, fits in well in a kitchen. The software is just lacking. You have to wonder if the people who designed it ever tried to use it on a regular basis. Hopefully they'll address those in future software updates.
title: Great display, great sound quality, pretty mediocre software / features

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Chris
content: I have been trading in my original Echo Show and Echo Spot devices for the Show 2nd Gen and Show 5. Sound quality on the 2nd Gen, superior - you might not even miss a Sonos Play One (which I also have for my TVs) and this has an excellent screen.  Sound quality on Show 5, far better than the Spot. Screens on both devices far more useful than their predecessors.  If you are trading in Spots, be aware that the Amazon base for the Spot will work perfectly on the Show 5.  Saved us $20 x 2!  Base is highly recommended if using for a nightstand clock unless your nightstand is lower than your viewing angle.  Ability to have large clock on Show 5 is excellent for trying to view without the glasses at night.  FAILURE to allow for a large clock on the 2nd Gen - for instance if using for a kitchen clock with photo background like the Show 5 has - inexcusable at almost 3x the price.  Fix this Amazon.  Clock on the 2nd Gen is unreadable across a large room which is a complete waste of that beautiful new large screen.  I would like to have a slide show background behind a large analog clock, for instance.  Perfect for the kitchen or family room. Show 5 has a clock shutter - great for a bedroom clock.  2nd Gen is missing a clock shutter.  Why?  If you are setting the 2nd Gen on a shelf - in a family room for instance - be aware that if you intend to do video dropins you will need a base to lower the angle unless you like looking at the ceiling.  The angle on these was designed for standing at the kitchen counter (just as long as you don't care that you can't see the clock) or sitting bolt upright at a desk with the device in front of you at arm's length.  Any other height/angle combinations and you are going to need the base to get a proper view of the room.  These devices are vast improvements over their predecessors - but - several missed opportunities for simple softrware value adds. Glad to own these, but waiting anxiously for software fixes for some obvious misses on the 2nd Gen.  The top of the line should have ALL of the features of the lesser devices available, not a subset of the Show 5.  Amazon wrongly assumed that people would want a giant clock on a small screen but would have no use at all for a giant clock on a large screen .  The great sound from the new speakers will soothe me while I wait for the software fix.
title: 2nd Gen - If only the software lived up to the screen and speakers...

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Steve613
content: Look, this is a beautiful product.  Huge, High Def screen, great sound, etc.  The only negative is - we're still waiting for fun exciting things to do with it.  We hooked it up with LifX lights, Ring doorbell and cameras, and the new Amazon plugs.  All that is great, you can turn things on and off, but with the exception of the Ring video, not much needs the beautiful screen. We use it to video chat with the kids & grandkids, and I think the stationary, hands free Echo is better for video chat than having to hold a phone.  But let's get some more fun and interesting video content going!!
title: Huge improvement over the first version

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Jack
content: I purchased this echo show to both entertain and keep an eye on my senile grandmother. I assumed it would be nice to choose photos to show her while also having a somewhat automated video chat option she didn't have to learn to use. Simple solvable software choices made by Amazon make this desire impossible Before this purchase I'd been an avid regular Echo user, I have one if every room of my home with all my lights, music and other electronics fully controlled by voice and found it convenient to reorder items. However, the words showing up on the echo show telling users what to try have completely ruined the opportunity to use this device as I describe above. My grandmother regularly becomes confused and aggravated after having been prompted to do stupid things ("Try, 'Echo' play Seinfeld on Hulu" prompting her to sign up for the service) or emotionally irresponsible things ("Try, 'Echo' call Mom?" which prompted me to have to explain to her that infact her mother had died years ago, again.) It is stupid that I have to leave an emotional review about this, there should be a menu option to remove text prompts, the online forums are full of this complaint but Amazon is too busy abusive warehouse workers and monopolizing cloud storage for all mainstream internet use.
title: Try "Echo, stop telling me what to try!"

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Adam
content: I've had the Echo Show for a month now and there are things I like which are pretty much the things I like about any Echo device (I have 4 now). I like being able to access Apple Music from almost any room in the house and listen to almost any song I can think of. I had hoped the Echo Show would be the same for video. Sadly no. I replaced the Echo in my kitchen with the Show. I wanted to be able to watch the news or a TV show while cooking which is something I love to do. A glass of red wine, watching a dumb action movie and making a nice dinner is my idea of heaven. Unfortunately, beyond the limitations of only having easy access to Prime video and Hulu (you can access YouTube and Netflix more manually), the real problem is the impreciseness of the voice controls. I've spent the last 15 minutes trying to figure out how to watch Season 4 of the Vikings on my Echo Show. Hulu has it, but everytime I ask to watch, "Vikings Season 4, episode 1" the Show brings up the correct search and offers to stream it through Prime or Hulu. Perfect, right? No, because although the search says Vikings Season 4, Episode 1 - if I select Hulu then I get Season 1, Episode 1. If I select Prime, I get the 1960's movie with Kurt Douglas (admittedly great but I've seen it a bunch). Herein lies the problem, I can't get to the content I want through the clumsy interface and simply opening Hulu ONLY shows a very limited selection of things to watch. 1st world problems, I know, but still. Basically, the Echo Show has me getting mad at Alexa all the time. The radio version of her is pretty smart. Give her the TV remote and she's dumb as a box of rocks.
title: It's an exercise in frustration with some glimmers of greatness

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: KajeX
content: I bought one of these and was excited at how big and bright the screen is.  I got it all customized to my liking.  Then when I went to listen to music, there was no sound.  I factory reset it and tried again.  No sound, even in the introductory video.  Contacted Amazon support and they decided it was defective and sent a replacement. Second unit arrived.  No sound.  Called support to try and return it.  I was connected to tech support who this time had me unplug the power cord from the back of the Echo Show and leave it unplugged for two minutes.  Afterwards, she had me plug it back in.  It now worked. I'm very happy with this device now, but have some serious concerns about its durability and longevity since it could not work right out of the box.  In addition, it lacks the privacy camera cover that the Echo Show 5 has.  For these reasons, minus two stars. All things considered, this sounds as about good as a very decent JBL speaker that was my previous favorite for music, and the screen is more vibrant than a Lenovo Smart Display.  I'm happy with my purchase assuming it doesn't need to be unplugged for 2 minutes every time I want to use it. Update:  After having this about a week, sound completely stopped.  I give up.  I'm not going to unplug this for two minutes every time I need to use it.  This thing is getting returned.  Two defective units in a row does not give me confidence that Amazon has a quality product.  This is in addition to being frustrated at the inability to turn off "Things to Try" messages.  It's a beautiful display that looks cluttered with all of the nagging messages.  So much potential here, but it is a failure.
title: No Sound???  (And Fix below)

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Phil
content: I have been using the 1st generation for almost a year.  This was on sale for a solid price.  I‚Äôve been using echo devices since the first one came out in early 2016.  And it‚Äôs still in use over 3 years later. I really like this 2nd generation so far. The initial process to get it going took maybe 20 or so minutes because it had updates. What do I like about this over the 1st generation? Here is a few things: 1.  The sound.  The sound is a lot more fuller for the room that it‚Äôs in.  The bass is substantially better.  It fills the room with plentiful sound. I live in a attached home and probably wouldn‚Äôt put it past 40 percent or so.  The thing Gets LOUD. 2.  The screen. It‚Äôs about 3 inches bigger than the first gen. And it‚Äôs way more vibrant.  Although my ring camera footage is a bit grainy to be honest. I feel like it might be a bit better on the 1st gen.  But most things the extra real estate really helps.  If you have weak vision like I do, it really helps you see the screen from the other side of the room. 3. Most of the Same features in a bigger form factor. Still has the same home screen as the 1st gen.  I have always enjoyed the home screen.  I look at the days headlines as well as the time and current temperature.  I have a smart home I guess you can say.  I like that I can check my Ring cameras and get a visual view of the current brightness on my Hue light bulbs.  Initially I was hesitant about getting one with the screen, but I really do love it.  Also things like song lyrics and answers to questions give you something visual to look at rather than just hearing it I noticed that this uses about 30 or so percent more power.  Echo show 1st gen has a 21W AC adapter and this 2nd gen uses 30W.  But if you factor in the extra 3 or so inches for the screen,  the 9 watt increase seems about right. So that‚Äôs just a few things that I have observed.  I will try to update my review over time. Personally I probably wouldn‚Äôt of bought it at MSRP price.  Echo devices drop in price pretty quick. The lower price point influenced my decision.  Lastly,  I will continue to use my Older Echo devices because they seem to last a while.  They just don‚Äôt go bad after a year or so. Overall good buy for me. 2nd generation has improved on several things for sure.
title: Good at sale prices

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: A Reader 4455
content: Returning it because of the constant "Things to Try" notifications on the home screen. I contacted Cust. Service and there's no way to turn that off. Also, it's lousy at playing anything online, like a video on YouTube. The voice and image do not sync up. Not happy with this device, it's going back tomorrow.
title: Continual Hounded by the "Things to Try" and It Can't Be Turned Off

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: D and J K
content: We've always liked the basic Echo.  This offered recipe reading,  better speakers, and a screen that could be used for displaying your own pictures.  (those features were good).  The fact that you can't control what comes on the screen, indeed can't turn it off (you can ask her to turn off video,  but it always comes back on,  even if you don't summon "Alexa").  This just gave us  background, irritating video noise that we couldn't make go away  (I don't want to glance over at the screen and see "do you want to check out....",  "do you want an update on COVID.?" etc.  )We chose to return it. We don't want or need something that introduces video pollution into our home.  It's like being in the airport or the doctors office where you can't turn the TV off.
title: Do you like video ads playing constantly?

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Alan H. Avella Macias
content: I bought my Echo Show last december.  I had always wanted this specific device.  Let me tell you, sound is just great, and I had used my brother's a lot and seemed perfect for my until... Well it has been my only sad story with amazon devices.  I have about 7 echo dots, and one echo show 5 (perfect little device). I have been using Alexa for about 3 years and the truth is I love it.  But a couple days after I received it it started freezing, rebooting and giving me Oh Oh!s messages.  At a point I just couldn't use the device for more than a couple minutes, so I decided to go for the warranty.  No problem there, as a label was sent to me, took it to UPS, following the proceedure, using the original packaging and so on. A couple weeks later, I received another unit, in an unbranded box, and oh surprise!!! No power adapter!!!, I though hey I am a tech guy so I found an old laptop adapter , changed the plug (compared voltages, blah blah...)  It worked and started finally using my Echo Show.  As expected, great sound but immediatelly I noticed... This must not be a brand new echo show!  It is way too Buggy!!!  Does not recognize my voice, It is way too slow, and integration with Spotify is awful, as it does not resume, freezes, sometimes it just shows the timeline of the song but not even a picture or info of the song, and for some reason it does not support the same languages my echo dot third gen supports.  Sometimes I speak to the device, and echos a couple rooms away answer "my call" instead of this one, sitting right by my side. I am not angry... I feel sad for Amazon... What is going on?  Too many sales?
title: Very Buggy

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: David M. Perkins
content: There are LOTS of complaints, and rightfully so, about the truly annoying "things to try" tips that constantly scroll across the screen 24/7. As of now, as far as I know, there is no way to disable this stupid feature. BUT there's one that's even WORSE! I have set up a slideshow that displays personal family photos on my Echo Show. It's pretty nice. A digital photo frame. The thing that SUCKS about it is that for every 3 or 4 of my photos that get displayed, Alexa inserts a photo of some prepared food dish and offers me the recipe. If I WANT recipes, I know how to find them online. I don't need them popping up every 30 seconds in my family slideshow. What the hell is wrong with Amazon? First, they ignore the THOUSANDS of complaints about the "thing to try" bullshit, and now they hijack your personal slides to show you pictures of food! I know Jeff Bezos isn't interested in my advice on how to sell products, but these stupid, annoying features should, at the very least, be optional. It's a quick software fix. Give us a switch to turn this shit off. Please! For this reason, I have discouraged friends and family from buying one of these devices unless they're willing to live with a billboard in their house advertising to them 24/7.
title: Alexa Hijacked My Slideshow !!

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: sjpatrick
content: If you like the original Echo Show, you will love this upgrade. The screen is gorgeous and the sound is incredible. I received this device a couple of days ago and hadn't yet gotten around to installing it. On this Saturday afternoon, I was in a Genisis mood. I asked Alexa to play Second Home by the Sea on my Everywhere group (which includes my original model Echo in my bathroom and the newest generation Echo in my kitchen and the newest generation Echo Dot in my laundry room. Never a surprise, everything sounded wonderful. Then I decided to dig in and install the new Show. The installation was falling down easy. I had also purchased the adjustable stand, which was a cinch to attach to the new device. I went through the obligatory first-boot software upgrade and after a few minutes, my Alexa website interface was communicating with my new Show and I was able to alter my everywhere group to include it. I played the same song. It was amazing. Fans of Genisis know that it is bass-intensive. This new Show thumps quite well for a device of its size. I look forward to deregistering my old Show to gift it to a friend at work. This upgrade is outstanding.
title: Excellent upgrade.

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Tatertot
content: I decided to break down and buy this...for me.....I am the techie one in the family.....but my 75 year old husband, as soon as I got it out of the box and played with it for about 5 minutes, I knew, it had to belong to him. He does nothing techie....but he does use my Echo all the time, his calender, music, timers, day and time, sports... He was so happy....still loves his flip phone, but loves his Show!  Wished others in family his age had a show so he could call them and see them....to cool for school, is what I say!
title: Surprise!

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Heather Burns
content: POS, commands that worked perfectly stopped working where you need to use now description, and any and all video feeds like say ring doorbell, wyze cam , etc... Etc... Only holds a video feed for about 15 seconds rendering it useless for a baby monitor, nowhere does it say on it anywhere that is limited on how long it holds a video feed, also any once a month no sound will play for no reason and have to reset it , and the last thing is it never activates quiet mode meaning when I have turned on quiet mode instead of yelling OK! to every request it's suppose to just make a quiet confirming sound that feature never works so regardless of what volume the music is set to or it being in quiet mode every response yells OK!! THIS THING IS A RIPOFF I have this and the Google hub max and the Google hub max destroys this in sounds , quality, features and understanding requests, biggest ripoff I've ever experienced I can't believe I wasted that much money on this , it will provide nothing but anger and frustration. I literally finally unplugged it and threw it in the trash because there's no refund available, as someone who's every house is a smart home with both Google and Alexa integration 100% choose Google if you are debating on the two. Rediculous product
title: Junk

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Nicholas
content: Bought this to help my father (who has Parkinsons Disease and whose hands are not longer able to operate a CD player) listen to his language learning CDs (which I bought on Amazon, ripped to MP3 and then uploaded to Amazon Music). Amazon - after touting this exact feature ("You can listen to all your music!") - then abruptly hobbled Amazon Music so you can no longer use it to play your own uploaded music, even if you bought it legally from Amazon in the first place (as I did). No explanation, just dropped it. If you want to play exactly what Amazon tell you you can listen to, then this might work. And if you want an easier way to spend more money on Amazon, then go ahead. But they've hobbled Amazon Music and who knows what else they may just decide to drop from the Echo if it doesn't match their business objectives in the future. Customer centric company? Alexa tells me different.
title: Not nearly as useful after Amazon hobbled Amazon Music

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Dennis M
content: We use one Echo Show (2nd Gen) downstairs and the other in our master bedroom to control lighting, front & garage door locks, Nest smart thermostats (2), Ring front door-bell camera, etc ... they have allowed us to retrofit, integrate and otherwise update our home into a "smart home".  All these functions we are able to execute & control just by the sound of our voice ... simply by speaking commands to Alexa.  Naturally, we can ask about the weather, temperature, celebrities, movies, etc ... anything you can type into Google we can now simply just ask Alexa by voice for the answers.  The music quality is excellent as is the video quality ... we often play some of our favorite music via Alexa (all for free) and even can pull up our favorite music videos via YouTube / Vevo.  This is an excellent product and everyone should have at least one. We actually still have our original Echo that we now placed in our master bedroom bath and purchased two more Amazon Echo Show 5s for our kids' rooms ... so we can all control & use Alexa conveniently from nearly any parts of our home.  And our son figured out that you can play the same music  via all five of our Alexa products at the same time to "pipe" music throughout our home like the old fashioned intercom systems. FANTASTIC PRODUCTS !!!
title: AWESOME !!!

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: PLTK
content: Have tried all suggestions on how to turn these off and none work. Many are really indirect advertisements "Try: Alexa what are the features of XYZ product. "  None are wanted. Otherwise, nice screen and good sound. But can't believe people put up with this. Mine is going back to Amazon.
title: Hate the forced "Try" recommendations at the bottom

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: Quinston Morris
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. Ordered it by voice yesterday (20 Nov 18) and got it on my door next day in less than 20 hours, thanks prime. Took about 10 min to do updates and everything and since I already have a Alexa account for my other devices it was preregistered and automatically connected to internet. The sound is amazing the attached video doesn‚Äôt do it justice. It has a pretty good sound wilder and IF you open a new card it‚Äôs 70 dollars off with a gift card so affectively after taxes I only paid 119 for it. You have to order by voice to get the early Black Friday price plus 10 dollars off first Alexa voice purchase then that‚Äôs how u get that 119 price line. Either way love it so far. Works perfectly with my nest camera. Takes no longer than the nest app to open up and show me on the screen. Sound wise I‚Äôd say it could used some extra power in the mid range but still a very powerful speaker. That‚Äôs all based on the past hour playing with it.
title: Great speaker, great smart display.

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: William Ball
content: I bought this echo show to add some flavor to my nights in the kitchen. My wife of 36 years, and I love music, and we banter back and forth on things as we prepare dinner. I thought, Hey, an echo show would be fun........ Wrong! The first one I received didn't have any sound. I got tech support on the phone ( now that's funny) and they said "the speaker isn't working" I said ....Really? So they ship out another and it has the very same problem. Yes the very same issue. However, I was able to fix the problem by unplugging the unit, and plugging it back in. Yup that was it. unplug, replug. Now this happened while the SECOND tech support person was on the line with me. She says, : oh yeah, that's what I was going to have you do".  NO she never mentioned that, and didn't even know I did it until there was sound coming from the unit. My point is this. I spent 250 dollars on the unit 128 dollars for Prime, 8 dollars for music. and wasted 3 hours of my time on two different nights sorting this out. GO WITH the Google home. I should have. and no I'm not associated with Google at all. I do not recommend you purchase this unit. It really, in the end, isn't worth it. I was excited to get one and all that excitement is now GONE! I really haven't used it since the first night. Don't really want to. If you want to buy it off me I'd be glad to get rid of it. Funny how Our time has no value to these merchants, never will.
title: Sound issues on 2 units

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: MD-11 Driver
content: I really wanted to give this 5 stars but could't based on a huge lack of customization, specifically to the home/standby screen. The Show lacks no built-in wallpaper or background choices like the Spot does, no color adjustment for the standby clock. The "Try Alexa" messages at the bottom of the screen are shown no matter what you are looking at on the screen. This is my biggest complaint which I hope amazon can get rid of or at least have a toggle in the menu to turn on/off in a software update.  Very disturbing to see when you are watching or reading something. Otherwise sound is very good with ample adjustments, web browser silk and firefox enabled work ok. Hope to update to 5 stars if amazon can get it right with a software update quickly! Google home has the display nailed!
title: Has potential

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: WhiteWolf
content: Ordered 2 of these trying to make it so my wife and 94 year old grandmother-in-law (who lives alone and hours away) would be able to see each other on a daily basis. There is never a mention of the fact that you need a smart phone to download the app to manage things, only found that out through tech support when trying to get my grandmother-in-law Echo up and working. She does not have nor does she want a smart phone.  Also see that not even a month later you can save $100.00 on a 2 pack.  Would have been nice to know then.  Wish I would have just bought her an iPad or tablet. Would have been cheaper and probably less confusing all the way around.
title: Research, research and more research.....

product: Echo Show (2nd Gen) | Premium 10.1‚Äù HD smart display with Alexa ‚Äì stay connected with video calling - Charcoal
author: mamashu
content: I purchased this for my 85 year old mother.  Was so excited that she could have face to face conversations with her children.  What they don't tell you is that you have to have a smart phone in order to use the skype feature.  If an elderly person had a smart phone, what would be the need to have this device?  After hours of trying to get her skype to work, I left and went home trying to figure out why it wouldn't work.  I finally connected her to my skype account using my smart phone.
